[bottom of page] They say that Everett and Angella have really made up again - he carried her to Bangor and visits there, which he has not done till recently, since she returned from the south. She has been engaged & disengaged a number of times. Says she never feels happy when engaged to him, so breaks off.
Completed

I have not been much acquainted in Northfield but have supposed it a bad place as to the character of it inhabitants expected? by the street. I have often heard "Old Mason preach he us'd to be called a smart preacher I doubt whether his preaching ever did me or any body else any good I recollected I us'd to think it more an abstruse dissertation than a Sermon us'd to hear many coarse and droll anecdotes about him. I shall not talk to you about being sick but I do fee somewhat dispair'd at the thought of you taking Chloroform and I entreat you not to do it again.  Although you seem to think it help'd you yet I dont believe it right to be taken except in extreme cases to be sure I dont know any thing about it but I have a right to be afraid of it. You seem to have a good deal of confidence in "your friend Field,, I hope he will prove himself to be all you wish. I feel a leetle apprehensive and yet I feel some ashamed of that same apprehension - for they tell me that I am too suspicious and apt to impute to wrong motive that which appears fair. Sometimes - and it may be so - But I know that at 25 or 30 years I was a unsuspecting credulous and simple heart as any one could be. It is very possible I've got to far the other way now.

Mother & Lucy                                                                                                                       April 28th 1848
Milo                                                                                                                                        Northfield
April 22 d 26th 1848
Completed

My Dear Son

                         There nothing in particular to write but as Humphrey & Mariah are going to Northfield I will just say that I am well & happy had the great pleasure of seeing very unexpectedly Mrs. Reed & Mrs. Vese two cousins of mine (old playmates) that I love dearly - had not seen them for a long time I have some things in your trunk you know I thought at first that I should have you send them here but on second thought I believe I had better when I have seen Sister Conant go to Northfield and make my visit there Soon I will let them be till then
 I shall calculate to go to Mr. Dickenson and Aunt Sister Esther to be there with me - let me know whether you need soon anything done about shirts if you do - & it is convenient for you to get it you can take from your Trunk a bundle of new cotton cloth with some linnen inside of it (it was not done u in anything or fix'd) up at all I believe - But I have other work here and it is of no consequence So out yourself to no inconvenience unless you will be likely to need before I can get your shirts done.
   How familiar and natural the great hedges & rocks and every thing about here does look
  write to me often do I want I want to know all about what you are doing and how you get along as much as if I was at Milo. I sent on a letter to the folks yesterday.
Completed

My Dear Son

  If you get this in season i.e before your uncle Joseph comes from Greenfield I wish you would send the stockings done up in a paper and label'd and Jane Aeyer Mariah wants to read it "Brother" Joseph thinks he shall not have to go to Northfield again for about 4 weeks - when I get your shirts done I will send them by stage unless I have some other opportunity should like to whiten them a while if you can do without them. I wish you would write to me and tell me, now and then, how you get along and if you have any letters from home send them. I expect to go to Sister Conants tomorrow

I left the Bosom you handed me with Jane for you the shirt I have got here I will wash it & send it with the others I am afraid you are needing them now.

  I shall go to some time next week to Mr. Williams if I can conveniently.
                                                                                                                     Mr. Parson will be coming every day this week
Completed

My Dear Son                                          june 19th

  I reci'd the bundle and a letter from you I am glad you have written to Uncle Pel. but I dont think it likely that he will come up & if he does it will be probably after I am gone you know that Anns Vacation is the 3 last weeks of August and I had better get through with my visiting and go to Boston as soon as about the 20th of August if your Uncle writes to you let me know and I dont know but it would be a good plan to let Uncle Enochs folks know that I am here and as they do visit at Royalston once in a while they may possibly make it convenient to come. I dont think I had better try to go to Lowell if they want to see me they can come to Royalston. I had a letter from Lucy as you know, & I sent it by Mr. Parsons the next day he said he handed it to Mr. Field the same day why have you not seen it.
 I am very sorry I did'nt call on Mrs. Piper got all - ready to that day I came away but the wind blew so hard I could not very well - had I better make my calculations to go to Royalston and return again to Warwick or go there last and start for home from there I shall probably be at Mr. Williams last part of next week. If you think it best and can conveniently come to Brother Josephs Some Saturday let me know when and I'll endeavor to be there

[In light pencil] The shirts I have made will be durable they are stout, but not very handsome. I could not do them up so nice as Lucy would the linnen is altogether to course Ann bought it I guess she was deceived about the fineness of it, keep the Handkerchief till I see you.
Completed

[left-hand side in pencil] the clock has just said 10 & as usual I am thinking of you & my other children. How I wish my dear Isaac that I could know what are your personal feelings on the subject of religion. I intend that you will not let your press of business and cares fill your mind so that you have no time for studying the Book of Books and for prayer - prayer keeps the Christian armour bright you must need your armour in such a place
[right-hand side]                             Warwick july 10th '48
my Dear Son

              Mr. Parson has sent for Brother Joseph to go to Northfrield So I'll drop a line or two I've got hold of a quill pen if it was only a good one I'd be glad I hear you've got letters from Lucy I want to hear or see it very much. I very much expect that your Uncle Pel will visit at Royalston this season but not till I am gone for probably he'll think he cannot come till after Haying. I have visited all the cousins in the other part of the town (and feel quite relieved) had a very pleasant tome tho' but you know I dont love to toss about from place to place any to well. However Cousin Joseph said he should be out here again this week & requested me to go back with him & I think I shall if he does for I shall be happy to see more of you & they are I suppose rather lonesome now
Completed

at Brother Josephs

My Dear Son                                                                                              Monday 24th july

                I feel a good deal disappointed that I cannot see you more. I had calculated to ride into Northfield today with Brother, but I conclude from what I can find out I should not be exactly welcome any where or rather it would not be exactly convenient Janes Mother is with her & in a few days she is going to Shelburne with her mother to stay awhile I dont see as I shall have any chance to see you at all. I spent last week with Sister Conant & should have stay'd there this week if I hadn't thought of going to Northfield. I did not go to Winchester last week - Guess I shall go down to Maj. Gales and Ms. Davidson's on Muddy Brook and try to get from there to Winchester and make a visit and get back here by next Saturday or it is possible I may go from there to Royalston But I guess not I believe the stage does not run from Winchester to Royalston now If I should go from there to R. I will endeavour to let you know. If I cant see you do let me hear from you often. I want to see the letters if you have had any I want very much indeed to know how Joseph gets along. I want to see Lucy & all of them so that I am almost homesick
 plenty of Blueberrys about here tho' I've not had much chance to get any wish you could have some of them
Completed

My Dear Son I have been here at Brother Josephs all this last week rather expecting to have a chance to get into Northfield but have now heard the Sad news that, Dear little Will is gone How do Joseph & Jane bear thier deep affliction. I have had an unusually anxious desire ever since I've been about here for thier Spiritual Welfare- they seem to be a lovely couple. O that this bereavement may bring them near to God.

  Probably it will not be best for me to go there at present if at all I should be glad to do anything for thier comfort that is in my power. But you know they have nearer and dearer friends. Do pray for them. I shall stay here till Brother returns from the funeral & then go to Sister Conants & perhaps to Winchester a few days. I had a letter from Almeda last night they were all well I guess they work very hard there - Brother Joseph goes to Greenfield next week (25th I believe) perhaps I could come with him if tis best but I doubt some tho' ? very much ended whether I had better at all I hope it will be so that you can go to Royalston while I am there?
Completed

Milo Sept. 15th

My Dear Son

                                              I have just ascertain'd that Ann has really determined to go away has written to the Committee of the "Ladies Society,, at Hartford - has receiv'd an invitation from them And concluded to accept it. She starts next Thursday is to be at Hartford 23rd of Sept. I have felt very bad about her going Still I dont know but it is best. It seems like her being thrown out upon the Sympathies of a cold unfeeling world. She is naturally too confiding and credulous to be away off without a Brother or Sister or any tried friend. I want you Should make enquiries all about the Schools and every thing in the west that would probably affect her.
  I know almost nothing about that Society - except that there is now a kind of examining Committee of Ladies at Hartford & that applicants for Schools are there going through a course of preparations Ann expect to be there till, and during the first week or till the 8th or 10th of October. Now I want you should be sure and write to her and give her all the information and advice you can. I fear She is going in the dark and will - Stumble
 you will know how to direct a letter to her I suppose  I wish I had a Report of the Society perhaps you have it - there are 2 Societies the one she is going to is the one that Governor Slade was President or Director of I dont know who is now.  Ann has been very useful to us all and to the community & a very disinterested person her great fault seems to be that she is not selfish enough to hoard up Money
  She has done good enough in Bangor in "training the youthful mind  in virtues path,, to be entitled (if Right ruled) to a good living the rest of her days. She is certainly too good a girl to be thrown away
Completed

I suspect she has suffered felt more keenly more the past summer in consequence of Josephs embarrassment his distanc'd & doleful look and hints about his helping her etc. than he is away of - on the other hand she has had to do a great deal for her scholars, to please them & thier parents and dress a great deal more necessarily than she would in some places.

   Charles has about as many vexations and perplexities as usual has not sold his oxen yet - you know how he borrow'd money bought Harness etc. He had a fine crop of Oats expects 300 bushels - But - when he had just begun to Harvest them he stuck a jackknife into his knee- Lame for a fortnight - meantime got what help he could - but they are part of them out in the field yet -grown skill'd out - and half wasted. It has rain'd so often that he could not possibly get em dry. 2 heifers died lately that he talked much upon for Cows. Sued for his taxes again etc. etc. Old Stove is worn out and Smokes so continually I can hardly live or breathe. He must get a new one. So much for the Sombre side
    He had let Pratt have 60 dollars worth of young Cattle towards paying for East lot. And has got one Cow, the Oxen worth 70 dollars & about 20 tons of Hay if he can sell them to good advantage he can begin to pay Joseph, his Dover note & Taxes etc. etc.
     Almeda is well her Children have been some unwell baby has been quite unwell 4 or 5 weeks. I spent most a week at Lucy's Mehitable was there all the time and Olive part of the time Came home with Maj. Furber Miserable old Slow horse with Mehitable to drive and most all the way in a pouring rain from 1/2 8 in the morning till 6 at night - rather dreary wasn't it.
    you dont know how bad I feel about Ann going away it seems as if I could not bear it tis so suddent and I dont know where she'll go I've shed more tears in three day, than in as many years before
Completed

The baptist People in this town are about building a meeting house. the Congregationalists have no part or lot in the matter Mr. Jones was building a house and teaming last winter he now preaches about every Sabbath but he comes on his teaming also by hiring a teamster

   I can think of anything else worth mentioning & I'm sure what I have written is not very well worth reading do write to much quick I can't imagine why I have not heard anything from Sister Lois I feel very anxious to hear I'm writing in the dark so I'll quit now good night
   I haven't felt like writing at all this time and perhaps I should make out better my ink is bad too good bye may 3rd   ? you and he be as a wall of fire round about you to preserve you from all evil
                                                                  A.M.M.
Completed

Oct. 12th - 48

My very Dear Son

                            I have heard that you wrote to Lucy that you have been sick but have not had the letters should have felt less anxious perhaps if I had. why did you not write me about it particularly. Are you not pretty well convinced by this time that tis best to take care of your health - And that cold water is not a Panacea for everything. I have no doubt that it is good in many cases - But perhaps not in every one. I do verily believe that you have put too much confidence in the Coldwater treatment- you may laugh at my fears and anxiety about you but you may find by bitter experience that it would be better for you to be a little more like other folks since you are flesh & blood and of "like passions,,.
  Ann is gone really gone is I suppose on her way from Albany to Buffalo today expects to pass the Sabbath in Buffalo I feel very anxious to hear from her again dont know yet whether she is to be located. Have you written to her you cant imagine how bad I feel to have her so far far away alone.
        Charles seems to want and mean to pay you something but thinks he cant now I shall talk about it now and then if he has no uncommon bad luck I think he will "wiggle,, himself in to a better condition in a year or two but in consequence of his not getting his oxen sold last winter & they got lame besides he had had to hire money to pay for them & then hire more to pay that, has lately been Sued by Rollins for an old disputed affair/tax about the bridge he built couldnt get pat for and wouldnt pay his
Completed

I suppose you hear from the folks at Bangor about as often as I do. Charles was calculating to go with his wife to make a visit at Hampden & Bangor this week (by the way Albina has hardly left home for a ride of pleasure at all) but there always some bad luck you know Nelly is so lame she cannot go at all be taken out of the barn leg smell'd very bad broke out in sore he dont know what it is but thinks perhaps it may be Scrachtes - it is so bad I am afraid it will spoil the heart

 I have just been reading your letter of Sept 2nd again I appreciate your remarks think them correct on the value of money when & where it is most needed & think we ought to have made more exertions and if we could have had a full and realizing understanding of the case in all its hearings we should have helped you more if we had to make great sacrifices even to distress ourselves to do it but tis fault we cant recall it perhaps we had better think it is some way or other all for the best possibly it might not have done you any more good than it will now if ever you get it C. says tell him to say what he thinks it ought to be and I pay it as soon as I can says you ought to have it and wishes you could have it
 I wish you could get a situation on the Eastern or St. Laurence R.R. so as to be near to home and nearer the boys

The folks at Warwick will perhaps wonder that I have not written to them the reason it baby has been sick good deal to do good deal to think of Ann going now gone feel spiritless and sad mean to write before long do write often.

  There is a mixt up mess I have written it as and when I could pick it out and put it together as it ought to be if you can
Completed

I understand what you mean by Connected But I say we are connected. O how nobly! have we not the Son of God himself for our Friend had we not better be satisfied with that and Labor manfully as he directs. Will not the wages be sufficient for us think ye

 I do not wonder that you are doubtful and disponding Sometimes it is so often the lot us frail erring Sinning mortal - by the way I think you are in the main highly favor'd in having a happy disposition or praiseworthy for governing it as it seems to be you do seldom give way to despondency - your present situation as to society must be I think rather unfavorable to the enjoyment of that Peace which is as a River. The wretched unitarianism about there tho' I see clearly now that is is all error did disturb my mind somewhat.
   Look not my Dear Son for worldly emolument or honour or for self for self's sake as much as we need of these things will be added. But I would have you try try to get above the fear of man You have in your nature a very great share of timidity or delicacy of feeling a Gem which does not pass well with common minds - they dont know its value indeed you'll find very few that will appreciate it they will call it something else and treat it accordingly. I can sympathize with you exactly in regard to the art of speech. We are not connected you say alluded? but what would be the benefit if we were we are all too proud to make any advantage of it if we were - your position is such that you perhaps might easily ingratiate yourself into old Mr. Everetts favor so that he would interest himself in your behalf, but you are to proud to do it you cant stoop, nor any of the rest of us - especially Charles he has bad trouble and cost in consequence! with Rolling Everett etc. Tho' there are many things may be Done without stooping - Charles by "Drawing in his horns,, keeping out of sight the sharp corners using a little "soft soap,, etc.etc.
Completed

Mr. Elijah rest of line is folded within the page self in a little small hole he has dug on the ground to dip out the water only large enough to dip a pail - it appears that he threw himself in backwards was not wet when they found him only his head & shoulder - had been sick a week or was very nervous probably deranged

Milo 12, Oct' 48

My Dear Son,

        Have this afternoon rec'd your letter Dated Oct 3rd Had just sent off one to you only the day before. I thought of waiting till I had another from you & now wish I had. Should not write again not but that you say you are Politics this fall and I want a little of your help am very glad of your letter to C. wish you would send on more such. He is determin'd to vote for Taylor. All I can do is to entreat him not to for I dont know enough to argy the case with him. He says tis evident that Cass or Taylor will be President - that Taylor is a good & will do right and he dont feel justified in throwing his vote away by voting for Van Buren or helping Cass ever so little by not voting for Taylor. If it was between Cass & Van Buren Should vote for the latter. That he is Free Soil but thinks that is the way to obtain it.
 You say Joseph A. is a good fellow I think so I had got an impression I cant think how or which way that he was very Shrewd and that he was a little inclin'd to be overreaching in his dealing (I have not been much acquainted with him you know) But when I look in his face - tho' he is evidently Shrew'd as well as cunning Sensible Smart, & inteligent I can see I think entire Truthfulness and Sincerity which makes me love him dearly. I do love him and his Jane nobody more with whom I have been so little acquainted.
Completed

your Brother Joseph sends Charles Walkers Free Soil Platform but it has nothing of Congress affairs or Speaches, Cheifly Slang or what is suitable for many of his readers I suppose C. reads the Bangor Courier now an then, But his eye right begins to fail a little I think tho' he is hardly wishing to know it and Albina wont hear it so he has no time not much to read but the evening and no time at all free from interruption from talk and taking the baby. She has so little of the intellectual and so much care and anxiety about getting the work along that it is a continual pulling down to him. It is grievous to see a mind like his so entirely fetter'd and smother'd by adverse circumstance

 In regard to Politics I feel sure that if he had just the right information he would stand just in the right place - this Prejudices in favor of Whig party are lack of information.
  Mr. Kittredge perhaps I told you has bought this Town i.e. all the unsettled land & I suspect he got it very cheap - for a Sing - I guess he'll do pretty well for himself isn't it mean that he has never help'd Albina a single dollar since she was 15 years old ever yet she has but quite lately got 10,00 of her school money that she lent him 3 or 4 years ago and that without interest. tis no matter however only on account of her feelings & I dont know as she feels very much about it
  September what a rainy month! Charles had a very fine crop of Oats but in consequence of his lameness and such very often rains he doesn't save perhaps more than half of them I guess more than a dozen times with all the
Completed

different fields he would get his Oats almost dry enough to go into the barn & there'd come a soaking rain

 He has got his crops all in now his Horse is some better of the lameness but not so as to use her
  You know Mr. John Gilman of this Town you know too perhaps that his wife is sick & has been 3 or 5 years Rheumatism Stiffness in her joins etc. has suffer'd exceedingly it has all along hurt her dreadfully to be mov'd (she is said to be a devoted christian and exceedingly Patient) - a year or so ago she got so the she couldn't lay more than 1/2 hour or an hour without being mov'd but it hurt her so to be mov'd that she couldn't keep from screaming. She has been growing worse and worse till she thought she could not be mov'd at all  ever since that Spring it has been thought that she could live more than a day or tow - And ever since about the middle July she has not been mov'd at all - lays in exactly the same position  and has liv'd till now!! Mr. G. told Charles a few days ago that she appear'd to be "stronger at the vitals than she did a month ago,, Tis horrid and almost miraculous - worms are literally devouring her & her bed nothing under her tho' they do every thing they can without moving her - by washing in Spirits & everything they can do. She has her senses perfectly and is so certain that it would kill her to be mov'd they have let her be thinking probably every day that it would be the last it is a monstrous - Strange affair and has occation'd some excitement there might and must be something done 2 of her sisters seems as if she ought to be mov'd and bed changed even at the risk of life. It seems incredible dont it. I think I've made a long story of it.  from your affectionate Mother A.M. Metcalf
Completed

Nov. 25th 1848 ..Milo

Thank you my Dear Son for your letter of 13 - 15 Nov. it afforded me considerable comfort as it induced a train of reflections which occationed heartfelt deep gratitude to God for his Goodness to me and real sorrow for my naughtiness and sin. I do not particularly rejoice at your promotion, as I feel apprehensive that you will not be able to sustain such a weight (of glory) or that the arderousness of your labors will be to much for your health in either case it might be matter of regret you know

  However I have been led to see how greatly I have blessed in my children in very many respects. I have very seldom when praying for my children asked for temporal blessing - yet none of them can be call'd destitute of these - and what great reason I have to bless God that they are in so good a degree rich towards Him may the Holy Spirit make them all abundantly more so
 I had along after I return'd from Mo. conjur'd up a great many little vexations & unhappiness (foolish & perverse was I)
  I felt sad & lonesome Lucy was not here Ann was going away off which was really trying - & then the little close bedroom & Smoky stove bad wood Alme so negligent & children so ragged and Albina seem'd coarse & disagreeable in voice & manner but I have got the better of it tis all pass'd away I am quite comfortable & happy. A. & her children are now all fix'd up nicely for winter She has a great many helps (present) from her neighbors her toungue is a fine instrument in her favor She has faults tho' not very great ones, after all and she really

[left-hand side] Does Joseph A. work with you now what does he call his babe
[top of page, upside down] Mr. Tash has a school f 60 or 70 boards them himself more than 200 attended the Teacher Institute
Completed

really is a very superior woman she is a much better woman than she was a year ago She is becoming better known about in town and her good qualities appreciated: - Albina too has improv'd very much I think in the last year She & C. are uniformly kind and respectful to me

 the You are at Grouts where you say there is no Sabbath then why not go to work and make one - appoint a meeting head or sermon pray and thank your Maker for the privelege of so doing - every mans conscience is really on the side of religion you would find help more perhaps than you expect. With all your necessity of knowledge you could at least find something to say or read which would interest even nowaday? - perhaps the very reason that you are sent there is that you may be instrumental in saving some one or more precious Souls. I dont know but your mind is so taxed thro' the week that it would be too much but it would be a change which is next to and sometimes better than rest.
 Saturday night Dec. 2nd Folks all in bed as they normally are an hour or so before me (by the way it is the happiest hour I have in the day)
You say Direct to Grouts - What town is Grouts in or isn't it in any - J. & L. tell you get married I say get married but not till you get away from Grouts I rather think my choice would be neither (certainly not Olive - Charles says that 5000, wouldn't countervail the disadvantage and loss to him  - going without a wife so long what think of that heh?  

I dont know as we keep you sufficiently informed of the news about here  -perhaps you dont care much if we dont Mr. Bumps has bought Mr. Lee's from Mr. S reserves part of the house. Mr. Bilington going to move off to New Jersey next Spring a Mr. Ricker has bought the Crocked lot which
Completed

Charles had given up we expect Mr. Ricjer to move into the house with Almeda this winter and onto her lot in the Spring.

Mr. Wyman is going to Mass. to live with his Father Mr. Daniel Hamlin has bought Sam'l W. Furbers Farm I believe I told you before that Mr. Kittredge has bought this Town. Charles & several others have been today to look for the best place to build a bridge across pleasant River Mr. C.A. Everett has built him a very handsome house near Mr. Wymans on the Pleasant river road has Married Angella Dennett - his Father & Mother live wit them Angella has seemed to be very much engag'd in the subject of religion all summer I guess she makes one very nice woman.
 Lucy has not been home yet since she was married I am I dont know but- wickedly impatient sometimes about it It is as if I had hardly seen her at all - when I got to her house in Boston I was very much fatigued & Mehitable was ther all the time. How do you like S.W.F. I think he is a Strong Smart good natured rather intelligent man - but "between you and I,,  each of my children that have got married have descended Some would not think it - perhaps in the last case perhaps shall not by & by perhaps I ought not to say this Dont express it tis my vanity & weakness? but I do now think that L. is his superior certainly in some respects and isn't she as a whole.
 Mrs. Gilman is living yet 4 months since she has been mov'd many people have been there determin'd that it could & should be done and went away satisfied that is was not best so they say. Do write often I dont hear much from the children at Bangor Eliab never writes Lucy very seldom Joseph as you know when he has business we rather expected them home at thanksgiving the house seems lonely?
Completed

June 25th 1849

My Dear Son I reciev'd an excellent letter from you dated 17th for which except my many thanks. I plead guilty to Brother Joseph charge of not writing & - I retort upon him for he neither writes at all nor visits me - except he alone only once in almost 20 years while I who am so much less able to do it have been there 3 times.

 I am glad your employment is no worse than it is but on one account I do not like it. I want you should come home but Joseph says you must not. It seems as if there ought not to be any business that requires the entire and constant attention by the whole year it must be too hard too rearing. If I dont write whole letters I most always occupy a "Corner of Josephs. I fully intended to write you a long circumstantial one while Joseph was gone to Hampden but Albina was sick the whole time and I was not very well & I could not get much time or thought for it with two babies and all
 Charlie is a good natur'd clever little fellow but is a real driving energetic persevering child into every Mischief & Roguery The Eagle Story I suppose is true it occur'd near the same place probably was the same Eagle you & your Brother saw when you were after Blueberries wasn't it. I recollect you said the nest was larger than a bushel basket.
 There has been a good many chances - and quite an increase in the number of inhabitants in this town especially about the Mill. Mr. Wyman has Mov'd to Ashby his house is unoccupied C. A. Everett has built him a handsome house near Wymans his Father & Mother live with him Lucy did not so much as Call on Mrs. Angel Everett in all the 5 months she was here last winter. L. dont like her but I thought she ought to just call
Completed

I guess they have each thought that the other slighted them - I am Much acquainted but Angella seems to be a serious sensible good sort of woman at any rate Everett has very much improv'd in his appearance since his Marriage.

  you have probably recieved with Josephs last letter quite a disappointment - which I percieve by your last letter you have been preparing yourself for, by so confidently expecting him to visit you. He did before he went to Hampden walk to Almeda's & back again after resting a while - and ride to the post office with James to wait upon him but he is not able to do either now but his appetite is better than it was & I think he is gaining strength a little. I think he does read to much (you know how hard it is for him to be idle) I have been making him a Syrup of roots etc. mean to get hm to ride a little every day as he is able to - we have not much variety of food this time of year wish we liv'd near a market (on his account) & I had money.
 I rejoice that you have Such an agreeable companion in your Assistant. Please tell me the result of your acquaintance with the "Old Maid,, Do you write to Mary Tower now a days? Is Engineering good business if you can never have time to visit your friends or get Married even?
  The weather has been so exceedingly dry this long time that one field of Charles corn has fail'd of getting out of the ground at all which is quite disappointment it being highly manur'd in the hill he says is the cause this last sentence it well put together perhaps you can guess what it means

M.C.                                                                                                                    Mother
July 1849                                                                                                             June 26, 1849
Parkers                                                                                                                Milo

Mother
                                                                                                                              Milo Dec. 31. 1849
                                                                                                                              Goffstown Jan 3 1850
 It is Sunday night about none o'clock this 30th day of 1849. The Folks are gone to bed & it has just come into my head to scribble a little to you, tho' I've nothing to write that's worth the postage. Our family consists of Charles ' Albina the little one & myself. Mr. Gilman some of the time he went home yester noon. I have a good warm fire nothing to to Modest or make me afraid. The happiest hour in the 24 is sometime between 9 & 11 at night for me I am very comfortable and happy tho' all the time but I do enjoy being alone. C.A. & the little Charlie went to Hampden last Thursday home again last night had a very good visit. Fine weather - all enjoy'd it very much Lucy & her Folks all well - Lucy works pretty hard I guess John Furber boards there and goes to Hampden Academy. Our Candles are very poor so I've lighted one of your Spermacites - what a Beautiful light they do give & how long they last I have burnt only one before this but it has done me a "sight of good,,
  Nobody ought to love a child better than I do Lucy I Iot upon seeing her & Samuel I some expect to go there this week. I dont know how long I shall stay  Make haste and come home & I'll come up with you probably & had better not stay there very long. But I calculate nothing about it without knowing what Joseph is going to do. Tell me do you think he had better stay any longer there and in that Treatment I cannot ascertain that there is much if any improvement in his health. I suppose I dont know any thing about it, But it seems to me that having a steam of Water from 20 feet an inch in diameter poured onto him must be exceedingly painful, ? and exuuting to the system. I dont know hardly what or how it is but he seems to be ever since he has been sick rather too much inclin'd to follow out
Completed

exactly what the Doctors tell him whatever distress and suffering it may cost him. When he was taking those powerful stimulants last summer, it was considerable time after it was plainly evident to me and to him that it was injuring him before he would leave taking it and then not till he had written to Dr. Rich - when he had the same as told him that he didn't know what to do for him but he might by such & such things 

 Now Dr. Prescott has told him that he thought the Water Treatment cannot help him and has written to Eliab to that effect. I feel so distress'd sometimes to think he is there alone for strangers to experiment upon I can hardly bear it. He needs a kind friend or Brother with him. He has an exceedingly refin'd and exalted mind - But I think you even dont fully understand him he is not (now at least) fit to judge for himself in every circumstance as Eliab would be.
  I have all along thought his best chance if not the only one for him to get well was to be quiet & do nothing but wait and let nature alone conquer the disease. Still I've been afraid not to have him try.
 A while ago he wrote me that his hand and arm continued to fail  - in his last letter he said there were some symptoms a little more favorable but I didn't think much of it because he has so many time had his hopes rais'd from the merest trifles. If his lameness can not be help'd is it right to wear out and exaust his system in vain attempts so that he can never enjoy anything.
 But how I have run on & scratch I down my thoughts just as fast and just as they come into my head. But you must consider it and take it for what it is worth remembering it is only the cogitations of simple old woman but take care when you have read to burn it.

when I hear from you again which I hope will be soon I shall probably be in Hampden.
[left-hand side] The German Dr. had just come there that day but he seem'd to put great confidence in him.
[at top upside down] Joseph I suppose has written you that Dr. P. is gone from there & a stranger, a German Dr. was there and was going to take his place or the establishment would be broken up so Joseph wrote me enquiring whether he had better in case that Dr. did not stay go to some other establishment or to Hampden or to Milo.
Completed

Milo Nov. 6th 1849
          My own Dear Son
                                            I recie'd your good letter last evening with joy and great Gladness - it was really very welcome the more so perhaps because I am so very lonely now a days since Joseph is gone
  Albina is very clever & kindhearted and I have very many causes of thankfulness. And when I have the pleasure? of her company day after day all to myself I feel really grateful that I have Books to read & that I love to read them. But my eyes trouble me considerably this winter Smart & burn and more if I read much. Tis only in cold weather that they are sore much I wonder what the reason is. I can manage to let Albina do most of the talking & that suits me all the all the better. Lucy had inform'd you I suppose that she is not housekeeping yet - does not have the Hinman House as they expected but is going to take the Harthon House - they seem very happy Sam'l has improv'd very much since his marraige by means of her society notwithstanding her will seems entirely merg'd in his
  He is really a very fine man But she is if not his Superior a more Complete character than he a Mothers ? you know (Well,- of that sentence is not good grammar I dont much care)
 we had a letter from Ann last week
Completed

Joseph has before now inform'd you of his whereabouts and all about his journey he seems pleas'd with his situation and his Company. I was astonished that he should go from here to Bangor in one day and get from there to Mornay the next. O that it might do him good but I have very serious fears that the benefit if there is any will only be temporary. He needs more Company & more to interest his mind than he has had a good deal of the time the past summer; i.e. when he has refrain'd from Study which he did with a great deal of Self denial after you were here except when he was studying up his "letter of Mischief,, as he call'd it. He has always been too ambitious I guess.
 Perhaps you'll think from his going such a journey and bearing his journey so well that he is a good deal better but I do not think that his limbs are any better but rather worse.
  A few days before he went away in consequence of getting his foot against the rug as he was going acrost the floor he fell I was not in the room but he said he has to crawl on his hands and knee till he could get to a chair before he could get up & then with great difficulty though he should have to call for help. But he has never been willing to be help'd if he could possibly get along without. He says that they can tell him in four weeks whether the "Treatment,, will help him or not
Completed

how I dont want you should work to hard but perhaps it will be convenient for you to come about the time that he think but to come back which he had better do perhaps if he does not find the W.C. beneficial to him as soon as 3 or 4 weeks or if he thinks it does help him perhaps he might use it here at home - He did not think it was best for me to go with him & I think now that it was not - but I did feel very bad when he went away 
God bless you my Son and Shield you from every harm.

                                                                from your Mother

Mr. Gilman is at work in the east room. thinks he shall get it done in 3 weeks

Milo Nov. 15th 1849

My own Dear Son

                        I have just reciev'd a letter from you I had one before just the day after I had sent one to you. It seems you had not received it - what is the reason - I will not try to tell you what a good boy I think you are but my eyes will overflow with Gratitude to God that he has given me just such a Son. Thank you for your letter. How I do hope you can Stay a good long while when you come home. Your last visit home was like a very little taste of something good which only makes one long for more - more than if they hadn't tasted.
  Hope I shall see your report of survey & I think you must have had a great deal on your hands lately and more than your head full besides I'm afraid tis more than you ought to do. My health is much better than it was in the hot weather & I didn't really know but what I was well then in the time of it but now I know that I feel a good deal stronger than I did then.
  you tell about my giving good advice and the benefit of my experiences! Alas! I was never capable of giving good advice (tho' I us'd to try to sometimes - and my experience as far as my own acts are concern'd looks to me now like all Sin and folly - Besides the tables are turn'd now. I have grown old & must look to my children for counsel and advise not they to me

I suppose Lucy gets to Housekeeping about this time She has had many little disappointments and delay about it and has anticipated much happiness. I hope she'll have her health and not be disappointed.  
 You speak of my being there tis not much matter to me where I am where I am I shall probably spend a few weeks there Sometime this winter, but I think I had better not be there very long.
18th We had a great deal of rain within 3 or 4 weeks past not so very great a quantity but long rains the last week has been very warm and pleasant.
  Mr. Gilman & Charles have lath'd and plaster'd the room and lath'd again ready to plaster, & C. is going about it tomorrow
  I have had only one letter from Joseph since he went away felt sadly disappointed the 2 last Mails
 It seems he almost think he is getting better but I dare not expect much upon it. O what a mercy if he should get ell - but if his mind is spar'd and his disease can be arrested where it is How thankful we will be. Almeda 's foot is better so that she can get up and down stairs and all about the house without crutches but she is lame and not as well other ways as she us'd to be The Ricker family are there yet and will be all winter. they are a continual pester to her and expense besides they are exceeding destitute will be a real hang on to Charles.
  Sam'l has been buying flour I suppose he has wrote to you about it. He and L. both understand how to get and keep property and will undoubtedly be rich if they have
Completed

no great misfortune and withall they know how to use the things of this life as not abusing I trust - I was very glad of a little advise you gave her a while ago about reading. I think she is rather too much for work if indeed she is not just exactly right as I am very apt to think her. She has a mind very capable of improvement. She ought not to neglect it perhaps she does not. But I have thought that he is a little too apt to feel that she cant spare time to read.

  You know it was very dry last summer & the corn or any other crop anything else dd not come up very well where Turnips did come up too much & pull'd em up and beans planted them & he had over a 100 bushels of those he transplanted and watered everyone 2 or 3 times Joseph told him he wouldn't get pay for his labor but he think he has 

Charles works very hard (like the patient ox) (beside had another rib?so lame he couldn't do much else)from early morn to late dewy eve gets nothing to read hardly now he has no boy not hir'd man - is losing his taste for reading I tell him his eyes begin to fail & that hinder him some about reading.

  I wish I had some good Ink - this is so pale and bad I dont believe you can read half of it & tis no matter if you dont for it isn't worth reading.
                                                                                                                       good night my Dear Son

20th I intended to send this by todays Mail but it was not convenient. How it does rain and blow last night and today

Milo 25th July 1850

J.M. to I.S.

                       Yours of "19th early,,  reciev'd and Suitably ponder'd - Alfred will probably Start from here next Monday - 29th He has got to look about a little & get some money of Folks that owe him. Botanizing progressing; the Milkweed concern, that you brought in last day proved to be Lactnea elongata; the little homely yellow thing nasturtium palustre, quite a discovery.
  Asclepias incarnata identified, also a third species of Epilobium. Lycopus virginicus  (bugle weed) you well know. I find the other species-lisinuatus 2 or  3 times as large with lower leaves pinnatifid. Silene nochflora! found growing in Col. Lee's pasture!- but our principle discoveries are Hypericum multilum, a dwarf species, a few in high H. Ellipticum (of A.J to Mich.) which seems to be our most common Species of H. But the greatest thing is St. Andrews cross, a St. pater wort (ascysum) belonging pr Book to "pine Barrens N. Jersey and Southward,, St. Peters worts differ from St. John wort in being 4 Merous.
 Joseph's Cold has got quite well No. on list 3 hundred & fifteen quit  J M M 

Jose wont let me write any more A M M

J.M. to I.S.

                      In Statu quo. We have had a Powerful and protracted rainstorm which caught & damaged much Hay Charles had but two loans out which was about Spoilt.
                         Galeopsis tetrahit Hemp Nettle a labiate plant with strongly spiny toothed Calyx. Lobelia kalmii, one plant, found on the intervale; it belongs on Lime ledges. Mentha Canadensis, indiginous, two varieties.

Milo       
             J.M. to I S.
                                   August 1st. We got your 28th ult letter yesterday & already commence a protracted letter which into be "produced"  considerable if not more we had written 2 letters which you have not recie'd besides one special messenger sent last Tuesday of all of which you will probably soon be in the receipt. I have just finish'd examining the specimen you enclosed.
            The Scutellaria appears to be S. lateriflora. Alfred - found 2 specimens of it down south east in Webb's little wood patch, he could find no more nowhere.
    That Mark'd "prinos" I conclude with some confidence to be Andromeda ligustrina.
    That mark'd  "Strange tree from Henniker" I suppose to be Mulberry, morus nigra, a native of western N.E. & westward according to Gray.  the leaves nearly agree with those of the Southern Red bud, or Judas tree, so far as I can see from this specimen; But I dont think this has a papilionaceous flower as that, the Edible fruit however of Morus N. should be ripe in July. I can find nothing else much corresponding to it
  James laid up lame with some boils so that since Alfred went away I have nobody to go prowling for me, he'll be about again in a day or two

Aug 3 Nye has got back from California only stay'd 3 or 4 days and being frightened forth by fear of fever fled. Sir J.R. Billington & his ladys Soap-wrights, of Jersey City, N.J. here on a visit one new plant today Mulgidium leucophseum a compositae of the Lettuce tribe
[at top upside down] Have you written to Ann since you went away Do you go to Boston soon if so I'll have a message for you to Mrs. Child if you can have time to call there let me know - & whether you have heard anything from Warwick.

Aug. 5, Botanical business very dull. four Polygonums, neither rich nor rare, is all I have to report. You ask how Alfred answers - perfectly, nobody could be better just on par with yourself in that regard. your Pyrus (alias sorbus) americana has since this rainy weather has become revivified, Rosa nitida thrives & so does Lycopersicum esculentum  & the other Children of your planting

 That letter to Dole was sent today
 Aug. 8th Yours of 4th instant recieved yesterday  - There seems to be now a lull in florescence, or else my Collections are deficient. I had however an excellent native Thistle yesterday, tall, (4 -5 ft) with showy fragrant flowers, Cirsium muticum, in bushes head of the intervale
 Lobelia Cardinalis - I do not name all the additions to the list by any means, only those that are more or less worthy of note. present No. of the list 341,  It was 277 when you went away. The letter that was sent to Hennikers was of no consequence only to tell you that Alfred was coming and a little about plants.
 You speak of Alfred as Slow I guess his Slowness is much more in appearance than in reality. Your comparison as to cuirassiers and Light Horse is a tolerably good one considering that from your mode of life your have not been much conversant with Military affairs- Altho cuirassiers are heavily arm'd yet that is not their characteristic, their peculiarity is their complete defensive armour which is scarcely us'd by any other troops in modern warfare - the ordinary full arm'd Horseman mounted on beasts of large size are term'd dragoons. The lighthorse, for velocity in reconootering the country rather than for efficient service in the battlefield usually call'd hussars in Germany etc. and rangers in this Country. Alfred evidently belongs to the Corps of (to sheet No. 2)
Completed

dragoons but perhaps not so very Slow after all, he looks Slow & heavy but in reality walks fast and accomplishes a good deal of business in a given time. He practiced pitching loads of Hay. Charles said he appear'd to hardly move, but the load went off very quick, & besides he is stout - how he lugg'd seven half barrels of Pork in succession across a Carry when in the woods with Furber I do not stop to relate
I very much doubt the correctness of your opinion that the back bone of a fowl is a choice piece or considered to be so, please cite your authority & precedents.

I yesterday procur'd my first Vol. from Milo Social Library Viz. Bancrofts U.S. Tome 1er one dollar pr share

Aug. 9 you did not tell us in your last how the health of your young friend Mr. Putnam succeeds. In our recent letter from Lucy she complained that you did not write to her I suppose that you already know how that Sam'l is reinstated over the Mill. Alfred is without doubt mistaken in supposing that I grew better while he was here. If Alfred & "yank,, shouldn't happen to quarrel they will probably become great cronies by & by will they not

 Alfred has been quite serious & thoughtful for some time & you must try to have him under good influence
I am sorry you lost your specimen of orchidaceae I think probably they were Platanthera Psycodes (O. fimbriata of Bigelow) and P. blephariglottis. The last kind is white, otherwise considerably resembling psycodes but from your Meagre discriptions I can of course give

[at top, upside down] Your letters Mail'd Monday reach us Wednesday afternoon Have none of the learned gentlemen of your party got Botanical knowledge Tastes & Books. Blueberries are ripe which several zealous friends bring to me also raspberries
Completed

but a vague guess. From what inquiry I have been able to make I think P. psychodes have not been found in this Vicinity, but that ours are all P. fimbriata. the grandiflora of Big. The variations being but the different degrees of luxuriance in the growth etc. The specimens I have examin'd this summer vary considerably in appearance but all unsensibly melt into each other in All of them many of the characteristics of both according to Gray, are combin'd Gray's descriptions of these species appear to be very imperfect he has by no means seiz'd upon their distinctive Characteristics with his usual accuracy. Bigelows descriptions are perhaps better, you are probably mistaken in supposing psycodes to grow on our Riverbanks, the specimen not yet blossom'd which you brought, from there, ad for that the day before you went away remain'd in our pitcher till in full blossom. I think it the same species with that in the Swale; the flowers are alike tho' the leaves and general appearance are somewhat different. James had a boil on his knee but is quite well now.

  Write more particularly what & how you are doing, the occupation & prosperity of Alfred, Yank, Everett & all others you may suppose usself to be interested in
Charles has hir'd a crocker chap call'd Charles Perigro half a month for 16$ pr month he probably get a pretty good trade for the lad is a great deal more than 16 inches high

[upside down] Lucy writes that she is well and Smart and going is going to send Lucy A. home next week & that Eliab talks of coming up soon.

The Mother to her own Dear Son                                                                  Aug. 5th

 you want to know about Charles's Haying - he went down after Boobar once before you went away I believe- well he did not come & didn't come - So last monday he went again found he had hir'd out with another man for money and he promis'd Charles should have the money soon. I expect it will be good when he gets it. Mr. Ricker has not help'd him any till today- he has had no help but John. It has been dull cloudy weather most all the time since you went away 

a pretty good hay day today only a shower about middle of the afternoon, & wet the lot of hay so they could not get it in  so the hay is to wet to rake up etc.

   we have had hot weather a remarkably good time for things to grow the corn and vines etc. My Tomatos in particular look finely I expect to feast on them by & by - the early peas are ripe & gone we sav'd them along for Josie the others, and string beans are now. I have been writing a letter today to Mr. Dole for Joseph with this same pen & ink do you think he can read it? wont it be nearly as legible as his (Doles) last letter.

9 Aug you see I've got some better ink now if I was only a penman and had some good ideas to write however it is not as if you was not going to have any thing of the kind from Joseph. You didn't perhaps call on Antoinette at least you give us at least some slight reason to suppose so as you did not say a syllable about her. Dont you think I feel interested in her welfare in every respect - one beauty Elm that in the corner of the dooryard is dead. The garden dont look so neat as when you were here but the things grow finely. I hope you will do your duty carefully to Alfred he will bear being a favorite a Confidant / i.e. he is faithful I guess  I guess but of course you may not have such an appearance much
[left-hand side] you say you are not going to kill yourself I hope you will not only not kill yourself but be very careful of your self

Cedar Grove                               Milo 1850

J.M. to I.S.
Aug. 10 we sent a letter to you by this morning' mail which is deem'd a sufficient apology for beginning another. I dont get many new plants now a days but under the shade of the appletree at the Corner of the piazza Mother suddenly found a strange one of novel appearance & structure, the flowers were so exceedingly minute that I could barely with decern with my magniscope that they were of Singular appearance, without obtaining any Clue whereby to outfind it. So I began at the Begining of the Book & patiently search'd thro it. I am now prepar'd to certify that it is a Pilea pumila, grows in "rich shady places" pr Gray. I was of course not surprised at finding it there when I learn'd the Common name, Rich weed.  another name is Clear weed in token of the semitransparent succulent stalk. I occationally study a while upon the heterogeneous bundle of nameless specimens & fragments which had accumulated. you know you & I look'd them over and nam'd what we could, & I had afterward examined those that I could get any Clues to, so that remnant are hard cases. Today I have been poring over them with unusual success, have identified two species of Gentiana , Gerinita & g. Andrewsic, both in a bad state of preparation being badly bug-eaten, found a large & elegant specimen, well preserv'd, of Andromeda ligustrina, the same which I suppos'd the plant you recently sent me mark'd "Primos?" to be. the leaves of your
Completed

specimen and much smaller however. I conclude you selected Small leaves as more convenient to send did you not?

  Two other specimens which appear'd to resemble each other somewhat I had laid aside and often gaz'd at, but was able to surmise what they were. As I journeyed to dinner casting my eye thro' the open window I discerned a twig of Snowberry & it straightaway occur'd to me that in general appearance it resembled my said specimen. I have just examined it & find the resemblance in the small flowers much closer than I expected, after long search the Snowberry is found to be Symphoricarpus racemosum, a native of western Vermont and westward.
 You have often remark'd that west of western Vermont a different new botanical region from this is found. I have recently learn'd the explanitory fact that it is a different Geological formation; the green mountains and Eastward to the coast and Gulf of St. Lawrence like the rest of the Alleghany ridge being a region of primitive rock.
Aug 12 bounded on the west by secondary (lower Silurian?) Formation. Since writing the above, O misery, I have after laborious & thorough Search been unable to find out said specimen So you see I wish I hadn't said any thing. Probably exotical & allied to said Symphoricarpum. Wool is, or has recently been 2/ pr lb in Bangor. We found Sonchus asper, a rather rare species, Sow Thistle. We have not found the Common species.
  Amaranthus Hypochondriacus, the red purple weed growing in your early remembrance as at Royalston Garden?
 It occurs to me Such Books as Bancrofts U.S. are better property & make a better Legacy to ones Children than such as
Completed

Pathetism, Kavanaugh, Friends & Fortune, Whipples Lectures, Hactenus etc. Altho' these are by no means the worst Books that ever was
Aug 14 Mr. Billington was here a spell yester afternoon. Report says that he has been making money fast, is going to hire somebody to build him a house, Stay at N Y while tis building & then come back here to dwell I have to write fast just what he tells me to, you see- et. all. all. 

  Mr. Kitteredge call'd here on his return from prowling about his Meadows bringing a hugh curious & rare insect which he had captur'd. It belongs to the Sinnean order Neuroptera
  I have made a beginning upon the difficult genus Solidago: have identified 3 species. I had apprehended much difficulty in determining these plants but have thus far outfound them with an entirely satisfactory certainty. I have also one species of Aster well identified. Diplopappus umbellatus of Gray, who divides the genus into 3 genera. Lucy A. Searles had got home from Hampden reports the folks at the Landing all thriving.
 Of course you know that H. Hamlin is reelected to the U.S. Senate (tho' Mother says you get no tidings) elected by Free Soilers in opposition to Whigs &/Hunker/ Democrats! Nominee for Whig Governor, Wm G. Crosby of Belfast, formerly Sec'y of Board of Education,

15th I haven't got any new plant this long time that pleas'd me so much as this Campanula aparinoides. the plant has something of the - (climbing) habit & appearance of a Galium, its small white flowers a little larger than those of Arenaria lateriflora, for which at first sight I would readily be mistaken, call'd Slender bell flower

   Polygonum sagittatum very properly call'd Tearthumb from its sharp sickle toothed stem angles is a pleasing discovery
  In the course of my meditations it occure'd to me that our Claytonia was the common C. Virginica & upon examination I find our specimens
Completed

to be C. Caraliniana! (C. spatulatu of Big.)

  The insects are eating the plants in my Herbarium 

16th Charles finish'd mowing today Seed hay and al, would finish haying tomorrow but for the generally elongated Shower. Have receiv'd from Mr. Theoph Sargents garden, Burberry, Gargot etc. Also a valuable plant, native to Piscataquis Intervales & by him Cultivated. I have seen it if I mistake not near Sebec hills. It is call'd climbing Stafftree, waxwork, Shrubby bittersweet, or Celastrus scandens
17 Eliab arrove here last night pr Stage and purports to stay nearly a week
21st Gnaphalium decurrens found on our home lot. "discover'd at New Haven by Doct. Joes,, a few years ago 100 plats added to our list since you left.
Eliab set sail yesterday on a birch canoe up Sebec Lake in search of a Northwest Passage (to Blueberries) Charles finishes haying today.
23d Lest he should not write you--He started from Milo to Village in conjunction with Stephen Kittredge & a birch which he had repair'd for the purpose. passing up Sebec river, in gunning at a Muskrat the tube of the gun (Charles's) was blown out, the Muskrat was nevertheless dying.   

 Up "half mile Rips" they waded dragging the Canoe;  Carried by Cushings Dam & reach'd Sebec Mill without incident notorious. There they borrow'd a Gun & hitherto forgotten ax & having Carried by relaunched themselves upon the greatly elongated bosom of Sebec Lake. They encamped at night near the head of the Lake, Some 20 miles from home. The Pickerel would not bite. Next day resum'd their pilgrimage, both by land and water, wandering round upon the, or an average, quite uneven surface, of the lake and various precipitous Hills adjacent. They came down the Lake favor'd by a fine breeze the waves running hillocks high. They therefore for Crosspiece hoisted a Coat on a paddle for a Sail and Sped. In coming home they astonished the natives by running half Mile Rips which at the low pitch of water is a highly unusual practice or feat of  which you may tell Alfred.  They were gone two days, brought home as many very large Blueberries as their limited accommodations would admit with Huckelberries intermix'd , also elegant specimens of Cephalanthus oxidentalis (button bush); Polygonum amphibium, 2 well marked varieties one of them particularly a Splendid plant & Corydalis Glanca. Eliab return'd to Bangor today. Your last letter of 11th was two days longer in the way than usual

26 Your Yank cuts 4?11  Cordswood in 3 1/2 days hey? Some of our Iron works are said to cut 4 or 5 cords of second growth poplar pr dieum

  You say you like Alfred better & better does he like the business? is he glad he went there etc? Tell him to write to me.  
  The reason for Saying that I do not get better is that I grow perceptibly weaker. Specimens thankfully received, upon which I as follows report:
    Lobelia Dortmanna, Water lobelia, glad to see it.
    Limnanthemum lacunosum floating heart " "
    Melampyrum pratense,   Cow whaet, is the one mark'd "Abundant on Mt Grace as well as here abouts." "dry Copses" pr GRay
     Hypericum mutilum Alfred found it about here
    Goodyera repens.  Rattle snake Plantain Closely allied to, sometimes included in, Spiranthes alias Neottia
    Geum Virginianum!  white Avens. it is a plant in its appearance and "leaves very variable." the specimen looks quite different from those you found before you left but both are unquestionably G.V. of Gray. Big. makes two species which run into each other by varieties. 
    Agrimonia Eupatoria, Agrimony, is singular and well marked by its "Calix-tube arm'd with hooked bristles, persistent, and enclosing the fruit."
    Epilobium coloratum is abundant here flowering since you left, both this & E. palustre, a specimen of which you brought from the bog vary greatly & probably make the many Sorts which you mention there. Possibly you may find E. alphinum, of "high Mts N.H. & V. New York"
                     I am greatly exercised about the little yellow one from Sandy shores of Specticle Pond. these being but one flower I dare not pull it to pieces I have labor'd much on it to no purpose. P.S. am becoming

inclin'd to call it Gratiola aurea, golden hyssop "borders of ponds & Sandy wet place" if convenient tell me if it is Stem creeping at the base also the linnean Class & order.

  I find here a new Hypericum (H. Canadense) & two Asters present No. of List 378
  I'm afraid so much of this Botany is getting to be an old and dull story but such as I have give I thee & try to make up in quantity for the deficience in quality. Charles has broken up an acre of grasswand which he preposes to Sow with Winter Wheat tomorrow N.W. Corner of Home lot.

Joseph has not taken any thing that can be call'd medicine since you went away roots & yarbs nor nothing Mrs. Weston brought him some nice Syrup which they made of Sassaperrilla etc. etc. but I cant get him to take it yet I dont know but he is going to by & by

J.M. to I.S. Aug 29 Instigated & aided by Eliab Charles dug many Rocks from the door wood yard several of which were large and remov'd with difficulty altho' thier tops were but slightly exerted. above this line is it right for me to write a lie he didn't remove them he only fill'd em up A.M.M. Yesterday John removed the holes with the oxen & cart Charles is Breaking up on the intervale today

  The principle plant this week so far is that abundant greyish looking Mint which we us'd to call Balm & which is now just in Bloom I am somewhat inclined to think it a new species if so a grand discovery isn't it. It is either not described by Grey or is his exotic Mentha arvensis with which it nearly but not fully agrees & of which he says "Sparingly naturalized in Westchester Penn. & in Central Ohio." Do you know if you have ever seen it at Foxcroft or anywhere but here?
Aug. 29 I have with considerable labor dug out our specimens, laid away for Geum virginianum (Syn. G. album) and upon careful examination find it to be Potentilla arguta! & of course entirely a different plant from the Geum V. a true and undoubted specimen of which you sent in your last letter this Potentilla however like some others of its section of the genus is a large coarse plant in aspect resembling Geum

30 Esq Lowney Cut his throat and died yesterday had a little Son born 3 or 4 weeks ago whose youngest brothers (half) Axil B. & Wm. S. average about 30 years old. Charles sowed his acre of winter wheat yesterday got it at Brownville gave 2,25 bushel - is breaking up another piece on the intervale today the point between the Swale . A new polygonum today 8th of that name P. dumetorum (10th pr Big.)

Sept 7 Lucy went home today has been here since the second inst. She & Jane came up in the Stage John came after them with Sam'l's horse yesterday. She is pretty well and smart for her hazlenuts are plenty like other wild fruits we are having some picked, come eat them.

Helianthus decapetalus is the plant in Lucy's Herbarium (by your authority I suppose) as Inula faleata
 The fern which we us'd to call Polypod growing in bunches by the roadside is at last found to be Dicksonia punctilobula!
  A new Solidugo today we have found but 3 species before, all of them exceedingly abundant these four kinds are all well mark'd & accurately ascentain'd. Among asters there is more confusion. Of the nine kinds which I have already got there is but 4 or 5 that I can feel certain about. four new plants today by Joseph & Lucy Hazlenutless.
           Your letter of Sept 1st was recieve'd by yesterdays Mail I dont know whether you have ever seen Richweed or not,  I presume tis common about buildings in some places. tis of the Nettle family, looks some like the brook Nettle made small, perfectly smooth & with pelluerd?Stem.
    I have got no microscope
   Of Gentians you had marked in Big. G. crinita & saponria, instead of the last this specimen (which I presume is yours) is! G. Andrewsiis closed gentian, a species not described by Big.
  The Children brought in the Compannula a. , I dont know where they found it. The Book says "Bogs, & wet Meadows, among high grass, prinicipally northward."
    Celastrus scandans was call'd valuable merely because I was pleas'd to get hold of it

James & Lucy went up on the Marston Lot after Hazlenuts

but owing to the recent exertions of Squirrels and Hatchlins, boys obtain'd nearly none, but brought me new plants

Sept 9 You may judge what a tall set of goldenrod we've got from the Sample. L. Altissima, S. Gigantea, & S. Canadensis more bigger either than

While Lucy was here last week we introduced 91 Plants into her Herbarium She had 103 in it before

  Thuja occidentalis is Super abundantly cover'd with fruit. many of the Small trees in the vicinage are completely orange-color'd with their ovoid cones

The bugs are eating the preserv'd plants, and I have procur'd a bottle of Smiths Liquid for the purpose. thick 12 Mos are very liable to break into and come to pieces Greys Botany is in danger of that fate it was poorly bound & will eventually require rebinding,
11  The Children went nutting again yesterday and got about half a bushel, also got 3 plants which were entirely new to me; Solidago Squarrosa. large Spiked golden Rod, flower most as large as thistle; an Aster with large flowers of "Mountains and Northwood," and burr Marigold with showy flowers; also the fruit of amphicarpaea monorea, which pr Book is rarely found, and a curious fruit of Ostrya verginica - a small clam-shaped Nut enclos'd in an inflated pupery - coriaceous clam-shaped Sack big enough to hold a score of then

My Own Dear Son I suppose you want to know more particularly than Joseph writes you about his health. His limbs get no Stronger as I can see perhaps his arms are not so strong and I have sometimes fancied that his voice is weaker than it was before he had that bad cold about the time you went away otherwise I dont percieve any thing but what he is as well or better than he was 3 months ago he gets up about 7 or half past lays down once in the fore noon & once in the afternoon sings & whistles & (hoots) while he is on the lounge has very Seldom Slept any in the day times since you went away not at all I guess since Alfred went. His appetite is good & his food does not distress him as I know of - but you must know that I have to guess in order to tell you anything about him if I ask him how he feels he'll only say how do I know, dont bother me. I guess he sleeps better nights than he did before you went away. Had he better go to taking Syrup etc. or not (Sarsaparilla, Burdock, yellow Dock, pipsissanwa & Gum quaiae & alchohol) Lucy come home Monday Stay'd till Saturday wasn't we glad but Joseph kept her most all the time writing and fixing and fussing about Botany. her own Herbarium tho' & she was very glad to fix it  Ann expects to come home the forepart of Oct. had Eliab better go out there to see the country and come home with her or not she wants him to & thinks it would be very much benefit to him

 How do you come on with your R.R. Shall you begin to "break ground" this fall. Charles's wheat & Oats are some injur'd by Rust because of there being sow'd to late he thinks has got his wheat in the stook is cutting the Oats. Potatos getting very bad is going to dig 'em,  soon as he can, and feed em to hogs etc. had got 9 little ones

 We are to have a Mr. Wilson who has lately been City Missionary in Bangor to preach here half the time the ensuing year the other half of the time he is to preach in Sebec. He is one of the Class just graduated at Bangor

J.M. to I.S.

Sept. 14 We reciev'd a letter from you last night. And we will commence a reply which will probably continue to accresce under our hands untill we recieve your answer to our last sent 2 or 3 days ago
  In relation to your difficulties with Messrs Steele, Chase, Crane etc. it will be of no use to say any thing as my remarks will be much behind the time before they can reach you.  Howsoever Edward Crane Esq., when I knew him was a good sort of a man I thought, Smart & a good business Man, a fine thing for you to keep the right side of him if you can He probably knows as much as  as all the rest of your R.R. folks together: it may be more as yourself call 'em a pack of Fools. He would be worth most as much to you in the long run as your firm friend as all New Hampshire, Dunbarton excepted, I have seen him frequently. Goss & Upham us'd to do a good deal of business with his Firm. My Friend J. R.K. Hayward of Bangor, formerly of Matamascantis, became on the right side of him and is quite a man thereby. If you were properly consulted about it I see no impropriety in putting? on another party if need be to expedite business. In that case you should not   " too fond to rule alone"
                      "Bear like the Turk no rival near the Throne"

It would to be sure be very appropriate to have such party Suspended to your authority, but if they were not I should think you had better put up with it rather than to leave so long as you remain invested with a separate and independant  command altho' it be a more limited one than you are entitled to
Completed

Whatever the true merits, it would be prima facia a bad circumstance for your reputation to leave that road now in any manner whatever. The obvious and dark-complexion'd fact would fly much faster and farther than the sufficient justifying, and perhaps to you highly creditable circumstances that caused it.

    Still for ought I know the state of the case may be such that you had better pocket the misfortune with fortitude & go on your way rejoicing/ If I understand it rightly Chase is not exceeding his powers he having been duly appointed Chief Eng. N.H. Cent. R.R. and never recall'd. So that the tortuous course of the directors and President has brought them into the difficulty of trying to Serve two Masters. I feel interested in the matter, write me when developements occur. E. Crane & Co. own timber lands and Mills on the Matamascontis.
   We have had Several rain Storms and much wet cloudy weather but no "great rains." Charles's extensive Oat harvest has been  much abshneted by the wet weather they are all out yet mostly raked however. Ann's School closes 20 of this month She expects to start for home about Oct. 1st She wants very much Elian to come out there and come back with her but I suppose he cannot consistently do it 

The plants that you sent were

   Krigia virginica, Dwarf Dandelion one of the smallest of compile plants I have become such a Botanist that I should probably have identified the plant if you had sent me only a single Achenium with its pappus. 
  Epiphegus Virginiana, Beech drops, Cancer root (Orobanche V.) is said to grow almost exclusively on the Roots of Beech trees is destitute of Green foliage
  Polygonum cilinode of "Copses, & Rocky hills Northward." But for
Completed

your word "wild" I should have inclin'd to think it Buck wheat but if turning or climbing which you do not tell me & I couldn't find out from the specimen it must be P. cilinode

  Belphilia hirsuta, I suppose the Mint-like plant to be tho' I am not entirely satisfied about it, I can find nothing else it will do to call it.   You will find perhaps on those Hills Aster graminifolens, a northern plant found on Mountains in N.H. - 6 to 12 in. high with linear leaves & small rose purple or white flowers: also perhaps some Mr. Solidagos growing 2- 20 inches high.   you do not visit Alpine regions I suppose at all

16 Sept I have had no new plants except as that you sent me, Since I wrote to you before. frost occur'd  last night & night before but Beans were harvested the Corn was ripe & the Tomatos were cover'd up Charles's grain all ready for housing Commenced carting it today there being so much of it in preference to cutting up the corn, the Wheat a little rusted but Pretty Good, is good generally about here

  Of those guinea Chicks the sole survivor at the date of the latest authentic inteligence the hen came off with one chick when she should have set a week longer,  after passing thro' divers disasters & dangers had attain'd the age of 4 days and had gone to live with its Aunt Polly.  
  Eliab mention'd his plant of going into partnership with Brown &Son but was advis'd adversely thereto. He will probably stay at Brown as long as they want him & pay him him his price. Mother retains her antipathy to that highly respectable firm notwithstanding the reported Mallifcation of its Junior Member. It has been quite healthy in Bangor this summer.
   According to my usual practice of having several Irons in the fire I have been reading of late "Bancrofts U.S. , Smellie philosophy of Natural History & poetical works of H. Kirke White.  In their respective limes the last are in my estimation much inferior in merit to the first
Completed

the last to be sure does not make great pretentions as the author died at 21,  and as the productions of a boy they are really great and good. If it has not already been done Some competent person had better at once set about writing a Substitute for Smellie. It is sometime since I read a book in which I found so much new & valuable to me as in Bancroft hadn't you better read it? Prescotts Mexico & Peru & Waverly 3 Vols are in the Library and I propose to read them

 We did not contemplate sending this letter for some time but it is found to contain 7 distinct propositions or ideas which is suppos'd to be much more than an average number so we conclude to remit it fourthwith

[left-hand side] we sent a letter last week if you are very busy you'll hardly find time to read them all
Mother & Joseph
Milo Maine
