My Dear Son I want to talk with you about Joseph bit I hardly know what to say he hardly allowed me to say any thing about him i e he seems to prefer to have nothing said to him of of him about his health therefore if I send this it shall be without his knowledge. He wrote to you you know the he was growing perceptably weaker he certainly is in some respects yet I dont know as I percieve difference except in his arms he cannot now move his left hand scarcely any without the help of the other one - he has not been out to eat with the family for several weeks he can possibly lift his tumbler from the table to his mouth but it appears to be is very difficult for him eats mostly with a smallest spoon that I have bought for the purpose. Yet I am not certain that he has (even his arms) failed any faster than at any time before but we should percieve it more now he is so week you know. It seems as if he wouldn't be able to feed himself a great while longer - but on the other hand Charles says that he can stand stronger or with less help than when he first began to take care of himm but probably if he is really weaker Charlie would not percieve it so much - he can lift him easier because he has got us'd to it. That's the reason that Alfred thought he was getting better. He seems just as he always has contented and happy keeps his mind fully occupied all the time with reading studying or something I have been trying to persuade him not to read so much It seems as if he reads with a more intense thinking and interest than most people so much so that he can remember and tell it all over. His mind is such that he cannot feel quite
Completed

at east if he has not something new to read. he is mov'd just where and when he wishes to be so far as he makes known his wishes he does sit up more than he did two months ago is mov'd about as often in the night as when Alfred was here sometimes 2 sometimes 3 times in the night sits up in the evening till 8 1/2 or 9 oclock since we have had peas beans squash etc he has prefer'd it and has made his diet almost entirely of vegetables

 I am some inclin'd to think that more meat if it was good fresh such as he likes would be better for him - it would be convenient if we liv'd near a good Market but he will hardly ever tell what he prefers. I have to guess at every thing about him. he sent to Eliab to send him some peaches and seems to enjoy them very much is very fond of them
  I suppose you are anxious to know ever thing you can about him. Therefore have I written perhaps you had better not give him any intimation of it
 his appetite is pretty good his countenance & he looks as well as he did I think his feet are not so apt to be cold as last year at this time. I dont know as Joseph would dislike my writing this if he knew it but I suspect he would for he did or pretended to because I wrote to you about his laying down so often
 I dont love to write anything that I dont let him read haven't before am writing with my papers in my lap when it is time I was abed doubtful whether you can read it all

Chickens are big enough so he eats them now he is very much taken up with "Prescotts Mexico  & Peru"
this is scratch'd off in such a haste I wish you would burn it even as you have read it

 I presume that Chrysopsis falcata or Golden Aster, (Inula F. of Big.) is not found in this region, it belongs on pine plains, & Sandy barrens, R.I. & Southward. It belong to Subtribe Asterineae, instead of Inuleae; and is in a different Tribe from Helianthus - grown only 8 or 10 inches high
 ("Our polypod" is not Polypod - much. Order filices has with as Suborder Polypodineae, of 16 genera; Osmondineae, of 3 genera,; & ophioglossaceae of 2 genera.  Solidago odora I have not seen, but presume it may be found across the River as it loves Sandy Soil, Solidagos, all authentic; & ten Asters of which however I can certify to but six. when it was written; e.g. it is said that all vegetables are similar om their general structure and mode of growth, and that of exeginous plants is given to exhibit it; thus not only ignoring, but expressly denying the existence of endogens and aneogens, which are probably very much more numerous. There is also running through it a tinge of romance or something which constantly is not philosophy. The chapter on the "progressive scale of beings in the universe" exemplifies this, and may perhaps be characterized as a somewhat wordy paraphrase of the fine expression of the same idea in Popes Essay on Man, enlarging somewhat on the culminating thought.

   "From natures chain whatever link you strike,
    Tenth, or ten thousand, breaks the chain alike.
    Planets & suns run lawless through the sky,
    Being on being wrecked, and world on world,
    Heaven's whole foundations to their center nod,
    And nature trembles to the throne of God"

Excellent idea's as poetry, and finely expressed in the Poem, but Sufficiently destitute of merit as Philosophy. The Rhapsody on, "die of a rose in aromatic pain" may be placed in the same category. These ideas are doubtless of high rank where they originated, in the conceptions of the poet; but when they migrate to the domain of philosophy their patents of nobility are no longer recognized as valid. Oct. 9 Your of 13 recieved yesterday. The Inulu that you enquire about is Inulu helenium, Vic. Elecumfrane. I think you may rely upon my Statements in regard to Polypods. P. vulgaris you sent me: our Polypod (so called) being Dicksonia punctilobula pr. both Gray & Bigelow, altho various Synonymes are given by both, as Nephrodium, Sitolobium etc. The plant in your last letter is Linaria vulgaris, Toadflax, ramsted,  "fields & roadsides, a showy but pernicious weed: Family Scrophulariaceae. Some weeks ago I recieved an elegant speciman from Mr. Dolins, where is was cultivated with great care ina flower pot, under the name of Butter & Eggs, making a more strong appearance, than, from your specimen, it does its Wild State.  

 Your Monograph of the Family Wilsoneae, altho' confessedly incomplete, is thankfully recied, you had, if I mistake not, been notified that Mr. Wilson was to be parson here in place of Mr. Temple, & had expressed your satisfaction with that arrangement; it was therefore thought unnecessary to accurately designate the individual. It may now be stated, however, that the subject of the enquiry was said parson, preacher, or stated supply Wilson. the given name is not at this time known to me

Oct. 21 In the New England Travels of one Dwight it is stated, that, as New England exceeds other regions in the beauty of its Autumnal Forests, so New Hampshire (particularly thirty miles about Lancaster) exceeds in that respect other portions of N.E. Do you notice such Superiority in your region? Poplar leaves fall early, and where they remain, take nearly the same yellow shade with those of the Larch & white Birch, so that the view from these windows partakes but slighly of the magnificence usually predicated of our Oct. J.M. to Artium Magister The latest instance of its raining pudding known to have occur'd in this vicinity  was the Concatenation of the recent freshet with the autumnal defoliation of the forest which caus'd a large deposition of leaves upon the riverbank. Cords of them have been carted to the hogyard. My Stock of Reading on hand is Bottus American Revolution, Vicar of Wakefield, Les aventures Telemaque, La Henriade, Rasseslas, Cowpers Poems, Scotts Poems, Macauley History of England, & Vols. Coopers Novels & 12 other Volumes in Milo Social Library. So you see that I am sufficiently endow'd for the present. Aug. 1 1851
Aug. 23  ~

                                                                                                                                           Bangor Au 1st 1851
 My Dear Dear boy
                                                 We have just recie'd two letter from you dated July 3 - & 15th Mail'd 21st one had been at Browns there a number of days Sam'l didn't happen to call there. It makes me feel very very bad to think you have not heard from us for so long time. We have follow'd you round with a letter whenever & whereever we knew where to direct. Tho' at Westfield, N.Y. Springfield, Ill. and Locust Hill care of G.B. Prooat & Perry Co. which last it seems was "not quite right- We have not heard a word from Ann Since    Eliab left here a week ago last Monday and we have not had a letter from him yet he is not generally so good about writing as you.  They were all, as usual. at Milo when we heard from there We wrote you how Charles was here went to Buckland to Temperance Meeting - & Mr. Lee Stop't here on his way to Ms. to open the summer, & Alice Sargent & Isaac Hoxie just from Wisconsin. Mr. Harlow is very kind carries me to meeting for which we feel quite obliged as it is rather far for me to walk

Do you get Eastern papers or learn much of what is doing here, where you are now. Do be taking measures to get on some of the Eastern roads if you can I am afraid to have you stay there
Completed

I am living ? here in idleness like a pig in clover- wish I could be making shirts for you or doing some good for somebody. I go a shopping some sorely against my ill tho' you know I had never hardly courage enough to go any where alone when I was younger but there is a necessity tain upon me now Lucy cant go out but Lucy really does seem to be getting well tho' very slowly  Sam'l talks of buying a lot and building a house here  Eliab did not know where he should go but had letters in abundance (of introduction) to many men in many Citys from Boston to N.Orleans I feel anxious about him I wish he could have gone with you to N.Y. & about 3 or 4 weeks & then home again. He needs more knowledge of Geography etc. but he will be getting some on his way I am some afraid he'll be sick he should have gone earlier or have waited till cool weather

  O how I wish you could be in good New England I am so afraid you'll be sick away there. Do be careful of your health. Do contrive to write often very often you dont know how thankful I feel that you do write often. I wish Eliab was a better boy about writing.   Mother says I must direct this. Samuel is eating his supper. says we have written every thing.
                 Uncle Natty talks of moving to Conn. on account of his wife's health. How many years would it take him to get away if he should really undertake? It is just dark - goodnight dear brother: May our Father in Heaven watch over you.

Bangor Aug 1- 1851

Our dear Brother

                                 It grieves & troubles we all to think that you have received no letters from any of us yet. when we have written so many times  - and you so far, far away from us all. I have written to Springfield, Westfield, Chicago and Locust Hill. We have been wondering much why you did not write, for some day. Today Samuel found a letter at Brown's store, which Walter said had been there some days! We are very much afraid your health will suffer in that Ill. Climate. I am glad you are not obliged to labor hard.
   All our letter have been running over with cautions about taking care of your health. Perhaps it is needless for me to add anything more. I have written you a great amount of news in all my letters, though I have most forgotten what it all was. Mr. Hartwell died tow or three weeks since. Col. Lee has gone to Ms.  He is very feeble - we could but fear he would not live to come home. Mary Tower is teaching school at Milo Village, and Lucinda at the corner. Two very big fires here since you went away - one swept almost the whole way out Harlow and Exchange Street from the Universalist church to the square - a very high wind. The other burnt several stores on the corner of Exchange  St right hand, as you turn from the bridge to Brown's store. Mrs. Noah Low, Mary Frost and Lucy are propounded for admission to the

[left-hand side] don't you think Mother some anxious about these dear ones away? Samuel is very busy as usual. He will write next time I guess. good bye.
Completed

church. The new liquor law makes strange work in Bangor as well as other places. In police expenses alone, it saves the city of $100. per week, it is said. Eliab wrote to you as soon as we rec'd your letter telling us to direct to Locust Hill, requesting you to write to him at Woonsocket R.I. where he intended to wait for an answer. He left here a week ago last Monday, and we have not heard a word from him - Nor from Ann since the middle of June. We feel very anxious to hear from you again lest your diarrhea should have returned again. I rode down to Hampden this morning - a young man died there day before yesterday near Mr. Crosby's - the circumstances of his death were very sad. He was a very fine fellow, 22 years old - had been at California two & a half years - on his way home took the Chagus fever,  (They call it) stopped at the Adams house in Boston, where he was robbed of his hard earned gold. He reached home and died in four days. His father two hundred miles away in the woods, exploring, and they don't know where to send for him. If you could get all the letters we have written, you would know every thing that has transpired since you went away, but I cannot remember to write it now. Mr. Tibbits is here now - boards here - finishing the house. Now for my health. In my last letter, I wrote in high glee about it. I was gaining very fast but during the hot weather that followed I melted down and lost my strength in a measure. It is now cool, and I think I am gaining again. My chair was carried up stairs three weeks ago. Then I went out round the house twice - now I get about the house on my feet quite comfortably. Do be very careful & write very often. Aff. Sis Lucy.
[left-hand side] I hope you will get this letter- I know how anxious you must feel to hear.

Mother Bangor Maine
Sept 6. 1851
Jonesboro Oct 1851                                                                                               Bangor Sept. 6th 1851

                    My Dear Son, 
                                               Eliab got home to our good joy Tuesday  Sept 2nd} his Health is better than when he went away He seems to have enjoy'd his journey. Spent a little less than 200,$ probably got his moneys worth perhaps more in health, knowledge pleasure etc. with a little sprinkling of Fatigue I should think thrown in along by way of variety. But he must write you all about that. Lucy & Sam'l are gone down river in pursuit of Health you will probably have a letter from her before you get this telling you all about her health. Sam'l late sickness etc. He was never sick a day before. We have you know (at least I have) look'd upon his prospects in regard to Health, Happiness and the Ability to obtain a large share of the "needfull,, as being very bright & promising. A good share of Happiness there is no doubt about he has it within himself. His labor & anxiety have been quite to hard this Summer. His Mill does not prove so profitable as he expected, his interest in navigation dont bring him in much. I guess, But however it will all come out right
   O if Lucy could only have her health. I can percieve that on the whole she walks round the house from room to room & generally by holding on to something. Dr. Rich & MCruen seem to think there is a tendency to Paralysis, and that it may be Constitutional but I dont really believe it
Completed

I know as little I suppose about the things at Milo as you do. I have had letters from there but once since I came away & then in consequence of teasing and scolding them. I have written home frequently. I know not much of the Crops on the Farm except that Charles wrote that the Winter Wheat look'd nicely better than he expected - till a few days before, the rust had taken it & he was afraid it would n't be good for much - the season has been very old - colder than for many years before there can be very little corn unless the very last few weeks of fine weather (but dry) has brought it forward, probably iy has very much, & if the frost holds off late there may be some. I think I shall go home in a few weeks, I want very much to see the children and know how they all get along there

 How long do you expect to stay where you are or on that road. I think you ought not to be backward about taking all the pay they'll possibly allow you - for I am sure I should want at least one thousand dollars a year more for doing the same Service there than in some comfortable places in N.E. Health, Society, religious priveliges etc. all considered. Eliab says he is well but he dont really seem to me like a well man I guess he is determined to stay at Browns as long as he lives which I fear wont be many years if he does. How much healthier & happier he might be  on a Snug little Farm with a disposition to enjoy it- & a good discreet wife, help meet for him
  warm weather today (Sept 9th) as any we have had this Summer & very dry & dusty it is sickly in this little City Dissentary and similar complaints

Mother, Lucy & Samuel Bangor Maine
Sept. 25 1851
Mt. Hawkins Oct. 15

back in Jonesboro, Oct. 27, 1851
                                                                                                                  Bangor 25 Sept 1851
My very Dear Son
                                           Your letter of Sept 2nd & 7th reciev'd I think we have learn'd your Mount Hawkins address now - but what a long way off it is. Are you really contented there or only make believe. It seems to me that the idea of making money is all that can reconcile you to staying away off there "1000 miles" out of the world  I suppose I might write what would be news to you if I knew how
  Friend Harlow [your uncle natty] has buried his fourth wife- is sick with a cold & lame himself. he has been very kind and attentive to Sam'l when he was sick offer'd his services in various ways gives us apples & plumbs etc. The Asa Walker place otherwise ancient Harlow place was Sold at Auction yesterday 2600$ to Albert Eewerson tis said that asa & his wife & children are going to California. A great many of the smartest men all about here are going to California they say C. A. Everett, Col. Mitchel, & son, Hector, Jo, & ben Sargent, Henry Thomson, & I dont know how many more from Milo.
  We want to send you, Newspaper but we dont know whether it would be expedient 3 cents for every 1/2 ounce you know. If you dont get the News you want any easier way we will send, Sam'l takes the New York Independent only - you do get most of the R.R. news do you not - the great R.R. Jubilee celebrating the marriage of the Canadas, & the Ocean, in Boston tis
Completed

said more people together than ever before in Boston The President Fillmore & suit you. Elgin etc. etc. more than 50 thousand Strangers. There was a smart little Horticultural exibition this week at the city Hall. Premiums awarded for the first time. Sam'l has got so well as that he has gone into the Mill this week but does not work much. Lucy seems well all but her Walking Sticks, and she has the use of them so far that she walked about the house but she cant get up Stairs, or dance, or make a curtsey, or anything but just slide her feet along without suffering the penalty (the back aches, had a letter from home a while ago Charles was writing to you & to send you a letter directed to you at Milo from Alfred Holman. Alfred is discontented where he is with Mr. Furbers folks says he was green I thought you could have him with you perhaps if you want him

 If your Money was here Eliab could invest it to good advantage I guess I heard him say that Frank got 5 percent a month "shave" on a note. Eliab has just been here says he dont get but 6 percent for his money. I have just been down to Main Street with Eliab have my likeness taken Artist not there so came back without. I have just reciev'd a good long letter from Ann in which she laments your far off out of the world, unhealthy, expo's situation, says "Perhaps he will continue there some years, and that he cannot do deprived of either home or opportunity of mingling with & making one of an enlightened Community without becoming changed some what from 'Our Isaac' 

Some of her letter was in a thoughtful strain, not to say sad, she
Completed

feels herself a stranger alone & lonely says she has a contented and thankful heart, But does want to be remembered, to have a place left for her in all our hearts to which she can turn when she has perform'd her Mission etc. etc. I've just had a present, a much valued one, The "Evening of Life by Jeremiah Chaplin.
Sept. 26th Lucy says I must write some to Isaac this morning. I think from your representations that you are in a good place - a place where there is room for a man to grow to expand & become all that he has a desire and willingness to become for I take it that one must labor to attain to any desired end and if there is room and opportunity then go to work now it seems to me that you have this room and opportunity where you are, but you of course can judge best.  There is nothing of particular interest here now boys steal plums and are prosecuted men sell rum and are fined $20. and costs and what rum is found on their premises is taken to lay the dust and Oh how how dusty it seems as though it never was so dry before as this fall. The fire has been raging in the woods from here to Machias terribly There has never before been such a rush for California as now everybody seems to be off for the land of gold.

                                                                                                                                                          S. W. Furber
Completed

I believe Mother & Samuel have written everything there is to write, and Samuel is just going, so I'll send it off to the Office. Your letters being directed to Mr Hawkins was quite a joke. Eliab had three Independents and a Bangor daily done up to send to you, & then concluded not to send on account of postage. Eliab said it would be better to cut out an interesting peice (R.R. news etc.) and send in a letter now and then.

[upside down] Mother S & L

                       Bangor Sept. 26
                      bask in Jonesboro Oct. 27

Mother is going again today to get her likeness. Eliab has had an excellent one since you went away -perfectly like him. Did I write you that Ann sent me hers by Eliab? a little darling. Mother thinks of going home soon to make a visit. I can't let her go to stay. I must do up my letter. good bye Aff. Sis Lucy. Eliab will attend to the tooth extraction today I guess.
Completed

Milo 26th Oct 1851

My own Dear, far away Son I am hoping and expecting to have a letter from you by tomorrows Mail. If it informs me that you are well at the time of writing it Still you are so far away that I cannot but fear that at the Moment I am reading you may be exceedingly sick and troubled. If we have no means of knowing it for two full weeks or more you will only laugh at me I suppose when I tell you that a mere dream I had last night arous'd my apprehension for your health & safety. But I am not naturally Superstitious I believe & it will soon pass away. I do not worry about you as you & Eliab say sometimes. But I must be permitted to think of you- you could hardly wish me not to. And O what inestimable Blessing and Comfort there is in the thought that God is your friend, your covenant God, at all times a nearby help, and whatever he orders sickness or health, love or death all will be right and best

 Charles Albina & Charlie, with Almedas family are gone to meeting except Lissie who stays at home to watch the Cow & keep her from the Corn in C's field above the house which would have been in the barn ere now but there was not room by

[left-hand side] when Eliab was home he & Charles kill'd the Barrel Swarm of Bees the Honey is most of it very nice I wish you had some of it -  Do take care of your health money is nothing when compared to it - be not tempted to stay for money if your health forbids.
Completed

reason of Hay Oats Buck wheat etc. Jane & I stay at home to keep house & take care of little Joseph who is a nice Smart boy just beginning to run alone, a handsomer boy than Charlie except that his eyes are not so bright & pretty.  They are about to unite two Meeting house in this town- the Universalists one and the Baptists one tis expected that both will be rais'd this all and the outsides finish'd perhaps

  Charles thinks he shall have 300 bushels of Buck wheat has thresh'd 15 bushels & we are eating it in the form of hot fritters. Had a letter from Lucy yesterday she is really getting better -- gets up & down stairs & all about the house 

30 We had letters from Eliab & Lucy last night and what rejoiced us more than those, was we had one from you directed to Charles written Oct. 9th - & I infer from Eliabs letter they have had one from you of later date. Eliab is boarding at Lucys - Loafing his says, I think it will be good for his health to follow that calling for some little time at least. Lucy really seems to be getting well. But you have later inteligance from them than I can write I presume. I rather expect to go back to Bangor in a few weeks to spend the winter or a considerable part of it

We do all feel anxious about your health but we dare not advise you to come home now when the cold weather is increasing lest it should affect your health even more unfavorably
Completed

than Staying there I hope you are doing a good amount of good there which will be some compensation for the privations vexations and disagreables & perplexities & all sorts of bad feelings that you must have
31st It has been raining all this week has rain'd very hard most of the time for the last 48 hours and pours down still. The water will be very high & carry off what fence there is on the Intervale

  The Tribune is this week about half fill'd with Womens Rights Convention. What will it all amount to, will they prevail - and enable the "weaker Vessel,, to become the Stronger- & Shove the "Lords of Creation" into the back ground & make them "tend the babies etc. I could wish that they might ring about some reforms. One should be to break the iron rule of Fashion with which our City dressmakers Sway & govern completely even our most Sensible and well informed females & very few are aware of the entire absolute despotism to which they tamely, willingly submit they may not act but in accordance with their dictates of fashion, in regard to the color of a ribbon even, 
  Please tell me whether you have letters from Antoinette frequently or if you have got so far away that you break off all unimportant correspondence

or perhaps she has discarded you entirely - but I dont suppose I can know any thing about it by you, shall I write to her & find out Well I have written nonsense enough for once

                                                           God be with you my Son
Completed

March 27th 1852.
 My very Dear Son
 I am Sixty five years old the first of this month, & how like a dream it does seem to me only think of it almost seventy years spent & to how little purpose, when I look back I can not find enough of good to be worth counting or reconing any way, but I can see enough that calls for the earnest prayer for mercy & forgiveness & that the evil of my example of unfaithfulness and shortcoming and neglect of duty may be averted from my children.
  I feel disappointed at not seeing you this spring but comfort myself with the prospect of your being here the longer in the summer. It is so long since I have seen you& then you think of going away back there again & if you do I shall never see you much in this world. But that is of very little consequence if we may but all meet before the mercy-seat in Heaven no more to part.
   When I recollect that I lost one of the best of Mothers at 6 years old then was a neglected lacyney? in the family of my aunt most of the time for 5 years then with an illiterate violent temper'd Stepmother the petted, indulged only Daughter of a minister who had been previously married into a low Irish family wholy against the will of her Parents & brothers and the many vicissitudes through
Completed

which I passed even in childhood I feel the goodness of God in giving me a devotedly pious Father

 From 16 to 18 I was in the then Province of Maine about here & there some of the time teaching school but mostly in the family of my sister. At 20 was married and was as happy with my Husband & babies for 4 1/2 years as any one could be with an unrenew'd heart and all thought & care center'd upon this world. Then the inexpressible loneliness trials & perplexities of widowhood rendered doubly poignant by youth inexperience & ignorance of every thing I ought to know. But it was God who did it to bring me to to myself, or in other words to draw me to himself - and tho I have been all the way Stupid wayward and unfaithful & sinning he has been manifesting his goodness to me.
  And when your dear Father was snatched so suddenly away & I left with my four infant children among strangers like a slender reed in a stormy wind what could I have done without a God to go to - to rest upon & still He was my Stay my Covenant God -notwithstanding that I (wickedly perhaps) by moving to Milo deprived myself of the ordinances & priveleges of religion and became so unfaithful & worldly minded & was it not his chastening hand that left me to myself & tho' not to absolute want & poverty yet very very great poverty of comforts & conveniences of life so much as to dishearten & put down and make a body appear quite a different person from what they would in different circumstances & all this in addition to very hard labor without firm health & spirits to sustain it
Completed

But in all this way in which I have been led I can plainly see the goodness of God it has been all mercy - riches of mercy - & O how unmerited - & how he has blessed me in my children. What a blessing and honour to have such a son as Joseph to give back to my heavenly Father - an earnest of future blessedness
Ap. 1st Well I dont know how I came to scratch down all this stuff all about my foolish old self some sentences just begun others not finished. If I did not feel to lazy & incapable to write a decent letter I would burn this but if I conclude to let you have it, you will please do it for me

 you will have it that Mother worries - We perhaps I will conclude not to write any more nor say any thing about you & then of I do worry it cant worry you

But I do not - God grant that I may not be deceiv'd  I think that my heart is fix'd - trusting in God I have no trouble, vexation, or sadness from any or all other sources compar'd with that of my sinful heart Tis possible I may be mistaken but I think that I have a deep, constant, content whatever my appearance may be Can I have recieved so much good from the hand of God & shall I not take patiently willingly even joyfully recieve whatever he orders I have been a remarkable Monument of his goodness because while I have been exceedingly and provokingly sinful wayward & foolish He has followed me all the way along with the blessing of his mercies & goodness & Christ appears no near so precious to me as if all created Being & thing could never seperate me from Him
Completed

but notwithstanding I frequently shed tears and cant well help it especially if I get much fatigued- partly I suppose because I am getting childish from age and partly because I do see more of my bad heart as I grow older and have less care about other things but if that can be call'd Grief it is "joy in greif,,

 Mary Rower we suppose does not get a school here this term. I hope she will keep in Milo report says that her Match with a Mr. Somebody I've forgot his name is broken off.
   Lucy A. Searles has improv'd is going to make a pretty nice girl. I beg you will not worry about her board I guess they wont think it a hardship to board her here especially as she is able and does help & at any rate while I stay and Cook her board.

Sam'l had a pretty good faculty for putting money in his purse & willing to take it out again when needed his earning or profits of Mill. Scaling & lumber will probably be for the year $2000 or more - he expect to get about 300, this winter for scaling is buying hard wood lumber which he thinks will be a good profit - his family expenses are considerable- but I think it not very unlikely that his whole gains from May last to May next should be some hundred a per?2000$
well he is a real good fellow he deserves

                           in haste A.M.M.

[upside down] Mother April '52 Bangor Me
Jonesboro Ill. April 24, 1852
Completed

Dear Nettie

  Tell me in your next on a scrap of paper particularly how you have been ever since you left home, in regard to those particulars, about wh. I feel most anxious And if you are not right enquire of Mrs. G? L? what can be done for the promotion of your health. The scrap you send me shall be seen by no one but me.

Mother
Completed

Standing Rule for Writing                                   n.d.

I want you to being uniformly, to reply, as soon as you received a letter fr. home. Shd. you fail to receive or return from home in one month from the time of mailing, write again. That is; write as often as every month, whether you receive or return or not. Then shd. one of our letters fail, we shd. not on that account , fail to hear from you. Shd. we think it unnecessary hereafter to write so often, we will let you know. But for the present, let the above be the Standing rule.
Completed

Milo Oct. 23rd 1852

My Dear Children  I recieved a letter from Lucy last Mail enclosing one from each of you. I feel grateful for your kind attention in writing to me it reliev'd me of a burden of anxiety on your account and it afforded me much happiness to know of you safe arrial & that you had so pleasant a journey.

 O that you may both enjoy good health while stay there even in the enjoyment of that inestimable blessing I apprehend you may have to suffer very many inconveniences and anoyances but I hope you will not suffer yourselves to be discontented on that account for none are entirely exempt Tis the "common lot" You must not mind that "dirty faces and the stiff hair branching out in every direction,, But must love and act the missionary to the precious immortal Mind within.
  God fulfils his purposes in a great variety of ways - & beyond the ken of Man. Tis very possible that the whole train of circumstances  which occation'd  your going down into "Egypt,, were of his particular appointment as the means of accomplishing some great good even, it may be, the salvation of souls - & if but of one how great the event compar'd with the means of bringing it about
Completed

Almeda mov'd to Brownville Sept. 8th was married on the way home- her goods went the same day the children the day after. Ann & I with James went to Bangor the Thursday after you left there. & Lucy Searles came back the next day. So in order to have Lucy come home in time it was expedient for Ann & I to be away i.e. if I went at all which I felt very loth to do just then I stopt at Bangor about 3 weeks C. & his family had visited Mrs. Rider before I returned. And last week Charlie and I alone together with Nettie & the old wagon went away up there & stay'd four days & return'd "safe and sound,, I think Almeda has "better'd herself,, she & her children seem to be very comfortably situated  and very happy. I saw the young Mr. Rider & his wife & the youngest son Mr. Rider & his children seem to be plain everyday homespun sort of people and none the worse for that in my estimation they are really good, excellent, always kind & pleasant I guess, with plenty of the real substantials of life without the foolery and fashion - "Uncle Henry,, has bought her farm for $275.00-- Mr. Pratt gives up his Mortgage & Notes for 100, which has already been paid over and all settled. Mr. Sargent is now moving over here

 Charlie is by me with his usual enquiry "what for?" I just asked him what I should say to you he says tell 'em I'm a good boy & eat bread & milk and learn to read pretty well. He is indeed a better behav'd boy than when you were here his going to school had a bad effect upon his Manners
  They have got the Meeting house almost done, somehow I
Completed

cant feel like saying our meeting house perhaps it is because I dont feel right. We shall probably not have any more Congregational preaching in this town at present if ever

 I had a very good letter from Sister Conant last week notwithstanding the very small opportunity she ever had for getting any education I think there are very few women 71 years old that write so good a letter. She informed me that Aunt Humphrey My own Mothers youngest sister is dead. But one of my Grandfather Mayos 12 children remain that is Aunt Hazeltine who is 86 years old. Maj. Gale Charles uncle is dead - Brother Joseph's widow & Mariah live on the old homestead . I love the old place and rejoice in the idea that it is not sold to strangers I do want to see it once again & to see sisters once more If I could go, & could meet Brother Humphrey there how nice it would be.
 I suppose the children at Bangor have written to you all about Moving into the new house & how Lucy got tir'd and sick. And the great Lumbering apperation Samuel is engaged in, in company with another man Mr. Bradeen - inuching? as he expected some $15000, it seems that it must be a great risk for him but he feel pretty confident of success
 Probably Eliab feels rather anxious now a days will be married I suppose in the ensuing winter or Spring but has not got it fully settled in his mind what he shall do for a living and where he shall locate himself - will probably board with Lucy this winter or till he gets married but will be not earning anything
Completed

your Mother Milo Oct 23-
Du Quoin Nov.-27-/52 -
[right hand side] your letter was in the little Trunk in the bottom of the Cupboard which you took over many times. I found it there only yesterday.
I should think perhaps of something else to say but Charles is waiting so good bye may the Holy Spirit be with you to guide & bless you & to preserve you from all evil and return you again in safety to your affectionate Mother.
